p: Some clear recommendations emerge from this analysis. Since expert judgment is involved in assessing the extent to which uncertainty estimates are realistic, reporting multiple, rather than single, assessments of the confidence placed by experts in particular predictions will avoid false confidence in the results ( Wesselink et al., 2014). Furthermore, descriptive (as opposed to quantitative) presentation of results, especially when based on a consensus view, can help reframe uncertainty into statements about possible risks. In crop-climate modelling, statements that describe processes and trade-offs are likely to be more informative than broad uncertainty ranges ( Challinor et al., 2013).
